content: The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 may be cited as the temporary suspension of motor fuel taxes. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007, also known as the temporary suspension of motor fuel taxes, includes a provision to temporarily suspend taxes on gasoline, diesel fuel, and kerosene. This suspension period will set the tax rates to zero for specific categories outlined in the Internal Revenue Code. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 temporarily suspends taxes on gasoline, diesel fuel, and kerosene, as outlined in the Internal Revenue Code. This suspension does not apply to certain fuels used in trains, motorboats, or aviation. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 temporarily suspends taxes on gasoline and kerosene used for aviation. The suspension period lasts until the national average price of unleaded regular gasoline is less than $3.00 per gallon. The reduction in revenues to the Treasury due to this suspension is treated as taxes received under the original rate. The amendments made by this section of the Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 will take effect on the date of its enactment. SEC. 3. REPEAL OF EXPENSING FOR CERTAIN REFINERIES. The repeal of Section 179C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, along with technical amendments to related sections, is outlined. This includes removing references to Section 179C in various parts of the Code. Additionally, the transfer of equivalent tax liability to the Highway Trust Fund is mentioned. The repeal of section 179C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 results in the transfer of equivalent tax liability to the Highway Trust Fund. Amounts transferred from the general fund of the Treasury are based on estimates made by the Secretary of the Treasury. Adjustments are made as needed based on prior estimates. The Secretary of the Treasury determines transfers based on estimated collection timing of liabilities, with adjustments made for prior estimates. The amendments apply to property placed in service after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. FLOOR STOCK REFUNDS. Floor stock refunds are provided for in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. If a tax has been imposed on liquid before the enactment of this Act and the liquid is held by a dealer for sale without being used, the taxpayer can claim a credit or refund for the excess tax paid. Claims for refunds must be filed with the Secretary of the Treasury within 6 months of the Act's enactment. (b) Time for Filing Claims: No credit or refund allowed unless claim filed with Treasury Secretary within 6 months of Act's enactment. Dealer must request refund from taxpayer within 3 months if liquid held by dealer. Taxpayer must repay dealer or obtain consent for credit/refund. Exception for fuel held in retail stocks. No credit or refund allowed unless claim filed within 6 months of Act's enactment. Dealer must request refund within 3 months if liquid held by dealer. Exception for fuel held in retail stocks. Definitions of "dealer" and "held by a dealer" apply. Rules similar to section 6412 of the Code also apply. SEC. 5. FLOOR STOCKS TAX. Imposition of Tax: A floor stocks tax is imposed on taxable liquid held on the floor stocks tax date, calculated as the excess of the tax that would be imposed under the Internal Revenue Code if the taxable event occurred on that date. Liability and payment methods are specified, with the tax due within 6 months of the floor stocks tax date. The tax imposed by subsection (a) must be paid as prescribed by the Secretary, on or before the floor stocks tax date, defined as the first day after the suspension period. Liquid is considered "held by a person" if title has passed, and taxable liquid refers to any liquid subject to the tax under section 4081(a)(2) of the Code. The floor stocks tax date is the first day after the suspension period. The Secretary refers to the Secretary of the Treasury. The tax does not apply to liquid held for exempt uses or in the tank of a vehicle. No tax is imposed on certain amounts of fuel. No tax is imposed on liquid held in a vehicle tank. No tax is imposed on up to 2,000 gallons of liquid held on the floor stocks tax date, if certain requirements are met. Fuel exempt from tax under specific provisions is not included in the calculation. Exempt fuel held by any person is not considered for tax purposes. Controlled groups are treated as one person, following specific criteria outlined in the tax code. (g) Other Laws Applicable.--Provisions of law, including penalties, applicable to taxes imposed by chapters 31 or 32 of the tax code apply to the floor. Other laws, including penalties, applicable to taxes imposed by chapters 31 or 32 of the tax code shall apply to the floor stock taxes imposed by subsection (a) to the same extent as if such taxes were imposed by such chapter. The Federal Trade Commission will monitor gasoline prices in the US, determining the national average price of unleaded regular gasoline monthly. Reports will be sent to Congress and made available to the public online. SEC. 7. COMMISSION ON GAS PRICE RELIEF. Establishment of a Commission on Gas Price Relief by the Speaker of the House of Representatives to study high oil prices and propose revenue raisers within a year. Commission to have 9 members including the Chairman of the Committee on Ways and Means. The Commission on Gas Price Relief, established by the Speaker of the House of Representatives, will consist of 9 members including the Chairmen of the Committee on Ways and Means and Energy and Commerce, with specific appointment criteria for the other members. The Commission on Gas Price Relief, established by the Speaker of the House of Representatives, will consist of 9 members including the Chairmen of the Committee on Ways and Means and Energy and Commerce. Five members appointed by the Speaker, with at least two not from the same political party as the Speaker. The Chairman of the Committee on Ways and Means and the Chairman of the Committee on Energy and Commerce will serve as co-chairmen of the Commission.
